description: From Middle English druggen, which is possibly related to Old English drÄ“ogan.

entries.meaning: A person who works in a low servile job.
(derogatory) Someone who works for (and may be taken advantage of by) someone else.

verbs.description: drudge (third-person singular simple present drudges, present participle drudging, simple past and past participle drudged)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To labour in (or as in) a low servile job.
examples: Rise to our Toils and drudge away the day.
